message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath while playing sports, along with no other symptoms, suggest a mild form of congenital heart disease. Coarctation of the aorta presents with hypertension in the upper extremities and weak pulses in the lower extremities. Complete atrioventricular septal defect presents with poor weight gain and feeding intolerance. Double-outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect presents with cyanosis and poor feeding in infants. Atrial septal defect is a common congenital heart disease that may present with the clinical features listed above.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical features suggest a congenital heart disease that causes increased pulmonary blood flow, such as atrial septal defect. Coarctation of the aorta may cause decreased blood pressure in the lower extremities, and complete atrioventricular septal defect and double-outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect may cause symptoms of heart failure such as edema and hepatomegaly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a congenital heart disease, and the absence of a radio-femoral delay suggests that the aortic arch is normal, making option (A) unlikely. Option (B) is unlikely given the absence of cyanosis and pulmonary edema symptoms. Option (D) is unlikely due to the absence of cyanosis or clubbing. The most likely option is (C), as it can present with fatigue and shortness of breath during exercise, and the normal blood pressure suggests that the coarctation of the aorta is not severe.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath while playing sports suggest a congenital heart disease. Among the options, the most likely answer is Atrial Septal Defect, which presents with normal blood pressure, increased pulmonary blood flow, and a systolic ejection murmur that is louder at the pulmonic area. Coarctation of the aorta would present with a radio-femoral delay, while Complete atrioventricular septal defect and Double-outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect would present with symptoms of congestive heart failure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a congenital heart disease, and among the options, only atrial septal defect presents with progressive fatigue and shortness of breath while playing sports. Coarctation of the aorta would cause hypertension in the upper extremities, and Complete atrioventricular septal defect and Double-outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect would have different auscultation findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the most likely congenital heart disease is Atrial septal defect, which can cause fatigue and shortness of breath during exercise. The normal blood pressure and equal pulses in all four extremities indicate that there is no obstruction to blood flow to the lower extremities, ruling out Coarctation of the aorta. The other options are less likely based on the given information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical features of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath during physical activity along with an otherwise healthy boy suggest a congenital heart defect, and the absence of radio-femoral delay rules out coarctation of the aorta. The most likely congenital heart defect is atrial septal defect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms point to a congenital heart disease and the absence of radio-femoral delay indicates that the issue is not coarctation of the aorta. The absence of a systolic murmur in the pulmonary area rules out complete atrioventricular septal defect and double-outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect. The most likely option left is atrial septal defect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of normal blood pressure, normal pulse rate, and no radio-femoral delay suggests that there may not be a coarctation of the aorta. Complete atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) is usually diagnosed in infancy and may cause symptoms earlier than 7 years of age. Double-outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect is an uncommon congenital heart disease. However, the progressive fatigue and shortness of breath while playing sports suggest that the boy has an abnormal communication between the atria, which may lead to volume overload of the right-sided chambers and pulmonary hypertension. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is atrial septal defect (ASD).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The child has no significant findings except for progressive fatigue and shortness of breath, which can be caused by a congenital heart disease. Among the options, the most likely is an atrial septal defect, which can cause fatigue, shortness of breath, and palpitations. Coarctation of the aorta can cause hypertension and radio-femoral delay, while the other options typically present with more severe symptoms or have other distinguishing features on physical examination.
